Notes: Schools of Classes VII, VIII, IX, X and XII opened on April 4th.    Primary schools (Classes PP to VI) opened on April 18. However, children who are unvaccinated, and the day care and ECCD centres, were asked to wait for another 10 days to resume.    All colleges and institutions opened on April 4 or soon after, based on the preparation time required.    Instructions on school reopening were released by MOH on April 4th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220508191425/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/04-02-22-%F0%9D%90%91%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A9%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%A0-%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%9F-%F0%9D%90%92%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%A8/

Further relaxation measures were announced on April 4, 2022.    All meetings, seminars and trainings are to be conducted virtually. Physical gathering is discouraged. The entertainment centers will remain closed until further notice.    https://archive.ph/pyvOm

Relaxation measures are continuing as Bhutan opens up.    As of March 28th, all indoor and outdoor sporting activities will be permitted but without spectators. Tournaments are not allowed for now. Individuals showing symptoms of COVID-19 are discouraged from taking part in any sporting activity.    Archery and khuru are allowed but must be kept at a maximum of 10 players per match, until the final relaxation.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

There are no restrictions on gatherings as measures continue to be relaxed in Bhutan.    https://archive.ph/pyvOm    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

As of March 28, all public transport services must resume its routine schedule.    Further relaxation measures were announced on April 01,2022    Escort services for people travelling via India will continue until the international quarantine remains. But for convenience of our public, frequency of escort services will be increased. The testing requirement for all essential drivers will be discontinued.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/    https://archive.ph/pyvOm

There are no specific stay-at-home requirements except those testing positive are advised to self-isolate at home.    Caution is being recommended. We would like to request everyone to maintain caution as far as possible. We reiterate that Omicron is milder in comparison to earlier variants, but this does not mean it is âmildâ.    https://archive.ph/pyvOm

Relaxation measures continue to be introduced in Bhutan.    As of April 4th, The mandatory quarantine and testing for domestic travellers from high-risk areas are being withdrawn hereon. The high-risk areas include Thimphu, Wangduephodrang, Dukti chiwog under Yallang gewog and Jangphutse-Manam villages under Toedtsho gewog in Trashiyangtse, Merak and Sakteng gewogs in Trashigang and all bordering areas in southern Bhutan. They need not undergo home quarantine, either at place of origin or destination. Individuals who have entered home quarantine on or before April 3 will be allowed to travel on the enforcement date.     https://archive.ph/pyvOm

As of April 04th, for international travellers, the mandatory 14-day quarantine period is being brought down to ???????? ???????? ???????????????? ????????????????????.  Individuals who are already in quarantine and complete five days on April 5 will be allowed to exit based on the revised quarantine protocol.    https://archive.ph/pyvOm

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grants for individuals directly affected by the pandemic (now extended until June 2022) and a full interest waiver on loans contracted from April 10, 2020, until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waivers will continue until June 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045842/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grants for individuals directly affected by the pandemic (now extended until June 2022) and a full interest waiver on loans contracted from April 10, 2020, until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waivers will continue until June 2022.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045842/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
There are Coordinated Public information campaigns such as National Covid-19 Outbreak Phasing Map and Covid-19 Apps.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220305045834/https://www.moh.gov.bt/

The health ministry along with the Drug Regulatory Authority (DRA) has approved the use of COVID-19 antigen self-test kits in the country. The ministry approved the emergency use of the test kit as an increasing number of people are able to access it. Pharmacies registered with the DRA will be allowed to sell or distribute self-test kits.    However, individuals testing positive on self-test kits must report to 1010 for registration and monitoring by the clinical teams. The ministry will then facilitate immediate follow-up for vulnerable groups and monitor long COVID conditions.    Currently, there are around 60 COVID-19 testing centres across the country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220429191007/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=167880    https://web.archive.org/web/20220508193319/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/11-04-22-%F0%9D%97%A5%F0%9D%97%B2%F0%9D%97%BD%F0%9D%97%BC%F0%9D%97%BF%F0%9D%98%81%F0%9D%97%B6%F0%9D%97%BB%F0%9D%97%B4-%F0%9D%97%BC%F0%9D%97%B3-%F0%9D%97%96%F0%9D%97%A2%F0%9D%97%A9%F0%9D%97%9C/

Comprehensive contact tracing is being done by National and District Surveillance Teams.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319204413/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/10-03-22-%F0%9D%90%96%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AD-%F0%9D%90%A2%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%82%F0%9D%90%A8%F0%9D%90%A7%F0%9D%90%AD%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%9C%F0%9D%90%AD-%F0%9D%90%93%F0%9D%90%AB/

All other COVID-19 norms in practice, including wearing masks, avoiding gathering and hand washing must be observed at all times.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220319202750/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/12-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-on-%F0%9D%90%8D%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%B0/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220403032619/https:/www.gov.bt/covid19/27-03-22-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%AC-%F0%9D%90%AB%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%A5%F0%9D%90%9E%F0%9D%90%9A%F0%9D%90%AC%F0%9D%90%9E-%F0%9D%90%8F%F0%9D%90%A1%F0%9D%90%9A/

Vaccines are available for everyone above the age of 18 years. Bhutan has run a vaccination campaign for 12-16-year-old children, followed by 5-11-year-old children and providing booster doses to children 12-16 years old.     On April 18th, the health ministry rolled out the second booster or the fourth dose for those in the priority groups. The priority groups include the elderly above 65 years, persons with chronic medical conditions, all health workers, frontline workers and all outbound travellers above the age of 18. As per the ministry, close to 230,000 people are in the priority group.    Vaccines that have been approved include Covishield (AstraZeneca), Moderna, Pfizer BioNTech, and Sinopharm and they are fully funded by the Govt.    http://web.archive.org/web/20220418151636/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bhutan/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418160519/https://www.moh.gov.bt/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220418161150/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/24-03-33-covid-19-booster-vaccination-for-children-12-to-17-years-old/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220429190649/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=168108

COVID 19 vaccines and boosters were prioritized for the elderly.  There is a COVID 19 hotline for senior citizens    https://web.archive.org/web/20210527034238/http://www.moh.gov.bt/announcement-senior-citizens/    https://web.archive.org/web/20220429190649/http:/www.bbs.bt/news/?p=168108

Yes, some states require either proof of COVID-19 vaccination or a current negative test result and/or testing on arrival if entering from other Indian states. Additional quarantine may be required dependent on state of origin."    https://web.archive.org/web/20220515182333/https://in.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All travellers should  a. Submit complete and factual information in self-declaration form on the online Air  Suvidha portal (https://www.newdelhiairport.in/airsuvidha/apho-registration)  before the scheduled travel, including last 14 days travel details.  b. Upload a negative COVID-19 RT-PCR report* (The test should have been conducted  within 72 hrs prior to undertaking the journey)   or  Certificate of completing full primary vaccination schedule of COVID-19  vaccination**.  c. Each passenger shall also submit a declaration with respect to authenticity of the  report and will be liable for criminal prosecution, if found otherwise.  ii. They should also give an undertaking on the portal or otherwise to Ministry of Civil Aviation,  Government of India, through concerned airlines before they are allowed to undertake the  journey that they would abide by the decision of the appropriate government authority any  post arrival requirement to undergo home/institutional quarantine/ self-health monitoring,  as warranted.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220513133316/https://www.mohfw.gov.in/pdf/GuidelinesforInternationalarrivalsupdatedon10thFebruary2022.pdf

All fully vaccinated adult citizens (18+ and have taken 2 doses) are eligible for precaution dose from 10/04/2022. Eligible citizens can avail precaution dose at any Private Vaccination Center. Citizens should carry their Final Certificate of vaccination (with details of both earlier doses). Citizens should use the same mobile number and ID card used for earlier doses.    HCWs, FLWs and Citizens aged 60 year or more, shall continue to receive precaution dose vaccination at any CVC, including free of charge vaccination at Government Vaccination Centers.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220513073721/https://www.cowin.gov.in/

There are no restrictions on movements within Nepal with a vaccination certificate. Local and private transportation are available. Public transport and personal vehicles, including taxis, are permitted in the Kathmandu valley and must adhere to COVID protocols.  Violations of local orders may result in penalties. Long distance buses may be operating in some areas of the country. Additional restrictions remain possible in many locations.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211115064301/https://np.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html

Periodic press briefings and protocol sharing through official website as country returns to normality:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220107124348/https://mohp.gov.np/en  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf

All people are eligible for testing in Nepal, with results arriving within 24-72 hours.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117203348/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/coronavirus  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228213121/https://mohp.gov.np/en

Almost none contact tracing even during the third wave (Omicron) through Nepal.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220228213433/https://kathmandupost.com/health/2022/02/22/omicron-led-wave-is-on-the-wane-but-nepal-should-prepare-for-new-surges-experts-say

Mask compulsory everywhere outside. The government of Nepal has announced that failure to wear a mask outdoors may result in arrest and a fine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117203348/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/nepal/coronavirus

According to covid-19 vaccine tracker Nepal has approved 5 vaccine (Astrazeneca, Stupnik V, Covaxin, Sinovac, Sinopharm). See link below:  https://web.archive.org/web/20211018181222/https://covid19.trackvaccines.org/country/nepal/    21 more million doses to be delivered before June 2022:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf    Government began administering booster dose of COVID-19 vaccine for people over 60:  https://web.archive.org/web/20220117204601/https://www.reuters.com/world/asia-pacific/nepal-starts-giving-covid-19-vaccine-booster-shots-2022-01-17/    According to MoH Nepal, as of mid April 2022, 76.6% of the population have received the 1st dose and 67.6% are fully vaccinated. About 1 out of 8 Nepalese, 12.4% of the population has received a booster.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220131191839/https://mohp.gov.np/attachments/article/811/NEPAL%20COVID-19%20EMERGENCY%20RESPONSE%20AND%20HEALTH%20SYSTEMS.pdf  https://web.archive.org/web/20220307201443/http://www.xinhuanet.com/asiapacific/20220305/c56196aabeb8455abff9a196d31a61d3/c.html
No extra recommendations for the elderly  https://web.archive.org/web/20210823194223/https://mohp.gov.np/en
